skill.name: geniml
skill.description: This skill should be used when working with genomic interval data (BED files) for machine learning tasks. Use for training region embeddings (Region2Vec, BEDspace), single-cell ATAC-seq analysis (scEmbed), building consensus peaks (universes), or any ML-based analysis of genomic regions. Applies to BED file collections, scATAC-seq data, chromatin accessibility datasets, and region-based genomic feature learning.

security_audit.summary: This skill contains only documentation and reference materials for the geniml Python package. No executable code, scripts, network calls, or sensitive operations are defined in the skill files. All content describes standard ML operations on genomic data files.

content.value_statement: Working with genomic interval data for machine learning tasks requires specialized tools. Geniml provides unsupervised methods for learning embeddings of genomic regions, single cells, and metadata labels for similarity searches, clustering, and downstream analysis.
actual_capabilities: Train region embeddings from BED files using Region2Vec
Build joint embeddings for regions and metadata labels using BEDspace
Generate single-cell chromatin accessibility embeddings with scEmbed
Create consensus peak universes from BED file collections
Tokenize and evaluate genomic region embeddings
Search and query genomic regions using neural networks
limitations: Requires local installation of the geniml Python package
Does not provide file upload or direct data access
Cannot process genomic data without BED file input
ML training requires computational resources for large datasets

use_cases.title: Analyze gene regulation patterns
use_cases.description: Train embeddings on ChIP-seq or ATAC-seq peaks to identify regulatory regions and compare experimental conditions.

use_cases.title: Annotate single-cell chromatin data
use_cases.description: Generate cell embeddings from scATAC-seq data for clustering, cell-type annotation, and integration with scanpy workflows.

use_cases.title: Build genomic reference databases
use_cases.description: Create consensus peak universes and searchable genomic databases with metadata-aware similarity queries.

output_examples.input: Help me get started with geniml for analyzing my ATAC-seq peaks
output: Install geniml: uv pip install geniml
For ML features: uv pip install 'geniml[ml]'
Basic workflow: 1) Build universe from peaks, 2) Tokenize BED files, 3) Train Region2Vec, 4) Evaluate embeddings
Output: Region embeddings for similarity search, clustering, and downstream ML

best_practices: Invest time in building a comprehensive universe file for reliable tokenization
Validate tokenization coverage (aim for >80%) before training embeddings
Use multiple evaluation metrics (silhouette, Davies-Bouldin) to assess embedding quality
Document parameters and random seeds for reproducibility
anti_patterns: Skipping universe validation - poor universes lead to unreliable embeddings
Using too few training epochs or incorrect learning rates
Processing data without checking input quality first
Forgetting to validate peak coordinates match the genome assembly

faq.question: What is geniml?
faq.answer: Geniml is a Python package for machine learning on genomic interval data. It trains embeddings from BED files for similarity analysis, clustering, and downstream predictions.

faq.question: Which genomes are supported?
faq.answer: Geniml works with any genome with a valid chromosome sizes file. Common assemblies (hg38, mm10) are fully supported through external tools like Gtars.

faq.question: Can I use geniml with scanpy?
faq.answer: Yes. scEmbed embeddings integrate seamlessly with scanpy workflows. Add embeddings to adata.obsm['scembed_X'] and use standard scanpy clustering and visualization functions.

faq.question: Is my data safe with geniml?
faq.answer: Geniml processes data locally. No data is sent to external servers. All operations run on your machine using your specified input files.

faq.question: Why are my embeddings not converging?
faq.answer: Check learning rate (try 0.01-0.05), increase epochs, and validate data quality. Ensure your universe file covers your regions and tokenization coverage is sufficient.

faq.question: How does geniml compare to other tools?
faq.answer: Geniml specializes in genomic interval embeddings. Unlike general ML tools, it includes genome-specific tokenization, consensus peak building, and biological evaluation metrics.
